qas.question: What author's 20th century writing caused interest in pure neoclassical design?
In what period did Percy Thomas design public building in neoclassical?
Sir Edwin Lutyens' city planning in what city marked a shift in design?
What new design was trending after neoclassical?
Who reawakened interest in pure neoclassical design in the 2000's?
What type of building did Vincent Harris design during the interwar period?
Planning for what city marked the rise of neoclassicism?
What other area besides England experienced a strong Gothic revival?

plausible_answers.text: neoclassical style of William Henry Playfair.

qas.question: What style was powerful and eccentric by the end of the 1900s?

context: In the early 20th century, the writings of <a0_0><b4_0>Albert Richardson<b4_0/><a0_0/> were responsible for a re-awakening of interest in pure neoclassical design. Vincent Harris (compare Harris's colonnaded and domed interior of Manchester Central Reference Library to the colonnaded and domed interior by John Carr and R R Duke), Bradshaw Gass & Hope and Percy Thomas were among those who designed <b5_0>public buildings<b5_0/> in the neoclassical style in the <a1_0>interwar period<a1_0/>. In the British Raj in India, Sir Edwin Lutyens' monumental city planning for <a2_0><b6_0>New Delhi<b6_0/><a2_0/> marked the sunset of neoclassicism. In <b7_0>Scotland<b7_0/> and the north of England, where the <a3_0>Gothic Revival<a3_0/> was less strong, architects continued to develop the <b8_0>neoclassical style of William Henry Playfair.<b8_0/> The works of Cuthbert Brodrick and Alexander Thomson show that by the end of the 19th century the results could be powerful and eccentric.
